strong.em: ALL EXCEL ACADEMY SCHOOL SITES WILL BE CLOSED FOR THE REMAINDER OF THE ACADEMIC YEAR, PER THE ORDERS OF GOVERNOR CHARLIE BAKER.

p.span: All of us in the Excel community are concerned about the growing presence of the Novel Coronavirus (also called COVID-19) in and around our community. Below, you will find information we have gathered from the Centers for Disease Control (CDC), the Massachusetts Department of Public Health (MDPH) and the Boston Public Health Commission (BPHC) in an effort to ensure you have all the information you need. We will update this site as the situation continues to evolve. Check back often for the latest information. If you have questions that aren’t addressed below, feel free to reach out

Excel Academy Charter Schools is committed to keeping our community informed about preparedness and response to the COVID-19 Outbreak. The safety and wellbeing of our students, staff, and families is our highest priority.

ul.li: 4.6.20 – Memo on e-learning and students with Individualized Education Plans (IEPs) and 504 plans (English, Spanish, Portuguese)
4.10.20 – Letter from the Commissioner of Education in MA on Legislation Enacted on MCAS, SOA Plans, and Regional School District Budgets (English)

p.b: What to do if you are sick?
p.span: Your doctor is the best person to speak with if you believe you may have been exposed to or may be sick from COVID-19. There is an extensive healthcare network in place, and your doctor is an important part of it. If you are experiencing coronavirus symptoms including
p.b: fever, sore throat, cough, runny nose, muscle aches, shortness of breath or loss of smell
p.span: , your doctor may advise that you get tested. You may also contact these trusted healthcare organizations in the community. Testing and treatment for COVID-19 related symptoms is available at EBNHC and MGH Chelsea regardless of immigration status, health insurance, or ability to pay.

li.span: Information in English
and Spanish

p.span: Teachers will be available for student and family questions from 12- 2 PM daily, Monday through Friday. Your child can call or email his/her teacher to ask for support.

All advisors will be reaching out to contact families or students at least once per week to check in on how they are doing. You should feel free to contact your child’s advisor if you have any questions.

div.p: During our school closure, Excel Academy Charter School will continue to serve breakfast and lunch to our students. Meals will be available for pick-up Monday through Friday from 10AM to 12PM. We will have two central hubs where we will distribute food:

p.span: If you live in
or
, please pick up your meals from this location:

li.span: Hub 1:
li.b: Excel Academy High School | 401 Bremen Street, East Boston, MA 02128

p.span: If you live in
or
, please pick up your meals from this location:

li.span: Hub 2:

p.span: If you can’t pick up your child’s meal, please text “EXCEL” to 617-466-9384 and we will assist you in finding a more convenient location.
For questions please contact Rita Andrade or Estevan Puerta at 617-970-5355 (both of whom speak both English and Spanish).
Additionally, Boston Public Schools and the City of Boston will offer meals daily from 8:30 AM to 11:30 AM at numerous sites around the city, including:

li.span: Paris Street Community Center, 112 Paris Street, East Boston
East Boston YMCA, 215 Bremen Street, East Boston
Salesian Boys & Girls Club, 150 Byron Street, East Boston
East Boston YMCA, 54 Ashley Street, East Boston
BCYF Martin Pino Community Center, 86 Boardman Street, East Boston

p.span: In Chelsea, food will be available at the following locations between 11:30 AM-1:00 PM:

li.span: Mary C. Burke Complex Parking Lot, 300 Crescent Avenue
Williams Middle School Parking Lot, 180 Walnut Street
Clark Avenue Middle School front entrance, 8 Clark Avenue
Chelsea High School front entrance, 299 Everett Avenue
St. Rose School courtyard, 580 Broadway
View more sites in Chelsea in the COVID-19 Food Resource Guide from Healthy Chelsea

p.span: Many other sites throughout the city of Boston are available – see a full list of meal sites here.

li.span: Ongoing updates from our CEO Owen Stearns,
Boston Public Health Commission
, and the Massachusetts Department of Public Health.

ul.li: For COVID-19 news and updates from the City of Chelsea
For COVID-19 news and updates from the City of Boston
3.13.20 Letter to Families (English, Spanish) — closing schools March 16 – 27
3.13.20 Letter to Families (English, Spanish) — access during closure
3.16.20 Letter to Families (English, Spanish) — updates on closure — extended to April 7th
3.19.20 Letter to Families (English, Spanish) — updates on closure — extended to April 27th
3.27.20 Letter to Families (English, Spanish) — updates on closure — extended to May 4th
3.30.20 – Letter from the Commissioner of Education in MA (English, Spanish)

a.h3: Local Financial Support and Community Assistance

p.span: There are a number of trusted community groups who are providing direct assistance to families in East Boston and Chelsea:
Chelsea Collaborative:

li.span: The One Chelsea Fund will be providing direct financial support to Chelsea families who have been impacted by COVID-19, and the Chelsea Collaborative is one of the organizations helping get money to families. They are also looking for volunteers to help deliver food and other necessities, for those who have the ability to do so.

p.span: Mutual Aid East Boston:

li.span: Connecting individuals to existing networks of support in the East Boston community to maximize mutual aid.

p.span: United Way:

li.span: Individuals who have been financially impacted by the COVID-19 crisis can find assistance through United Way’s 2-1-1 service.

div.p: Please see our Covid-19 Family Resources page here for more detailed information.

a.h3: Outside Resources & Credible Sources of Information

li.a: Talking to Children About COVID-19 (Coronavirus): A Parent Resource

a.span: CDC prevention & treatment guidance for COVID-19
Boston Public Health Commission COVID-19 fact sheet (English)
Boston Public Health Commission COVID-19 fact sheet (Spanish)

p.span: Effective Monday, March 16th, 2020, Comcast is offering 60 days of free Internet Essentials to new low-income customers and is increasing Internet Essentials speed for all customers in response to recent and anticipated emergency measures associated with the Coronavirus (COVID-19). For more details visit:

Many of the same precautions that help prevent seasonal colds and the flu can also help to protect against other respiratory viruses. We urge all members of the Excel community to continue practicing healthy behaviors necessary during cold and flu seasons, including but not limited to:

li.span: Stay home when you are sick. If you are not sure whether you are sick, contact your healthcare provider for guidance.
Wash hands frequently with soap and water for at least 20 seconds. Use an alcohol-based hand cleaner if soap and water are not available.
Avoid touching your eyes, nose, and mouth to prevent the spread of germs.
Cover your mouth and nose with a tissue (or arm) when you cough or sneeze, and then throw the tissue in the trash and wash your hands.
Clean and disinfect frequently touched surfaces and objects, such as toys and doorknobs, especially if someone is sick.
Avoid sharing drinking glasses, cups, eating utensils, dishes, towels, or other items.
Avoid shaking hands and use other non-physical forms of greetings to avoid the spread of germs.

p.span: These steps, while they might seem basic, are among the most effective tools we have to prevent the spread of the flu and other viruses, including COVID-19.
In accordance with the

a.span: CDC’s Travel Health Alert issued March 4, 2020

p.span: , anyone who has traveled to countries with a Level 3 alert for the coronavirus (currently China, South Korea, Iran, and Italy) should stay home and monitor their health for 14 days after returning to the US. This guidance also instructs travelers from countries with a Level 2 alert (currently Japan) to monitor their health and limit interactions with others for 14 days after returning to the US.

Anyone – staff or student – who has traveled to the countries named in the Level 3 or Level 2 alert may not be at school within 14 days after return to the United States. If you believe this applies to you or a student with whom you work, please contact your manager, your school nurse, and Jocelyn Foulke.

Additionally, members of the Excel community who have recently traveled (within the last 14 days) within the United States, particularly to Washington, Oregon, California, and New York, may be at school so long as they self-monitor their health. These individuals should not be at school if they have any symptoms such as fever, cough, sore throat, etc. Self-monitoring includes taking one’s temperature and reporting fever or any other symptoms. Please reach out to your school nurse and to Jocelyn Foulke if this applies to you.
Staff who are excluded for this reason will not have sick/personal days deducted. We may revise this protocol or communicate further guidance on this topic in the future.

Schools across the world have been observing an increase in anti-immigrant and anti-Asian discrimination. As a community we are committed to ensuring that all Excel students and staff feel safe and protected when they are at school. Please contact any administrator directly if you are aware of instances of bias, discrimination, or bullying.

p.b: Q: What is Excel doing to prevent the spread of viruses including flu and Coronavirus within our schools?

p.span: Excel is taking a number of steps to reduce the likelihood of viruses being spread within the school community. These include:

li.span: Educating the school community on steps to prevent transmission of viruses.
Maintaining close contact with state and local health officials, ensuring that we are monitoring their guidance, and implementing steps in our schools as needed.

Working with our cleaning companies to ensure that cleaning follows the CDC’s recommended guidelines, including sanitizing frequently-touched surfaces such as door handles, stairway rails, and all bathroom surfaces nightly.
Working to ensure materials such as hand sanitizer and disinfecting spray or wipes are stocked throughout the schools.

Screening staff and students who have traveled to areas where there may be spread of Coronavirus; when needed, excluding staff or students from school until they are cleared by a health care provider to return.

p.b: Have any staff or students been excluded from school due to concerns about the Coronavirus?

p.span: Staff members who returned to the United States following travel to the countries named in the exclusion policy described above have been asked to stay home from school for the 14-day period recommended by the CDC. While we believe that it is very unlikely that the staff members were exposed to the Coronavirus, we have implemented this policy out of an abundance of caution.

p.b: Q: How long will school be closed?

A: At this time we have closed school until April 27. We have relationships with our partners at the Boston Public Health Commission and the Massachusetts Department of Education to ensure we can consult them if we do need to make a decision regarding extending the current school closure. Excel is committed to continuing to provide support to students and families during this time.
What do I do if I am sick or have a concern that I have been exposed?

p.span: As always, we encourage all students and staff to stay home if they are sick or have symptoms of illness.

Please call the school to excuse your child and speak to the school nurse if your child will be out for multiple days and you do not have a doctor’s note. If a member of your immediate is sick with the flu or exhibiting flu-like symptoms and your child may have been exposed, please call the school and ask to speak with your nurse
to determine whether your child should come to school.

p.b: Q: Have there been any cases of coronavirus or COVID-19 in the Excel Academy community?
A: No, there have been no known or suspected cases of coronavirus/COVID-19 among Excel staff or students.
Q: What do I do if I have recently traveled to China or another area where there is community transmission of COVID-19?

p.span: For the time being, we are asking all members of the Excel community who have recently traveled (within the past two weeks) to a country where there is community transmission of COVID-19
p.b: not to come to school until cleared
p.span: Please call your school and ask to speak with your school nurse
if this situation may apply to your family. Areas where there is community transmission currently include China, Italy, South Korea, Iran, and Japan; within the United States there is
in parts of Washington, Oregon, and California.
